parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1
Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.STUDYID

fields.definition: A unique identifier for a study.
fields.implementationNotes: While this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.
fields.label: Study Identifier
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: STUDYID
fields.questionText: What is the study identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.SITEID

fields.definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on CRFs that are shipped to each site. EDC: This should be prepopulated.
fields.label: Study Site Identifier
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: SITEID
fields.questionText: What is the site identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.SUBJID

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
fields.definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
fields.implementationNotes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTM Implementation Guide.
fields.label: Subject Identifier for the Study
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: SUBJID
fields.questionText: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMCAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] category, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
fields.definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
fields.implementationNotes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading, or a preprinted category value on the CRF and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.
fields.label: Category for Medication
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMCAT
fields.questionText: What is the category for the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSCAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] subcategory, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
fields.definition: A sub-division of the CMCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
fields.implementationNotes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be pre-printed on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer.
fields.label: Subcategory for Medication
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMSCAT
fields.questionText: What is the subcategory for the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMYN

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate if the subject took any (concomitant) [medications/treatments]. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
fields.definition: An indication whether or not any (concomitant) medications/treatments/therapies were taken/given.
fields.implementationNotes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.
fields.label: Any Concomitant Medications Taken
fields.mappingInstructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
fields.name: CMYN
fields.questionText: Were/Was any (concomitant) [medication(s)/treatment(s)/therapy(ies)] taken?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSPID

fields.completionInstructions: If collected on the CRF, sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
fields.definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, This is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
fields.implementationNotes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile concomitant medication/treatment records with AEs and/or MH. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.
fields.label: CM Sponsor-Defined Identifier
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target". May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
fields.name: CMSPID
fields.questionText: [Sponsor-defined question]

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMTRT

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Reported Name of Drug, Med, or Therapy

self.title: Reported Name of Drug, Med, or Therapy

fields.completionInstructions: Record only 1 [medication/treatment/therapy] per line. Provide the full trade or proprietary name of the [medication/treatment/therapy]; otherwise the generic name may be recorded.
fields.definition: Verbatim medication name or treatments (include only treatments with data collection characteristics similar to medications).
fields.implementationNotes: In most cases, the verbatim drug names or treatment will be coded to a standard dictionary such as WHODrug after the data have been collected on the CRF. For the collection of verbatim drug name or treatments, the recommendation is to ask sites to provide the full trade or proprietary name since it is more exact than the generic. The full trade name provides the base generic and the appropriate salt for that particular drug. In addition, for coding purposes it helps with ATC selection. For example, Tylenol with codeine #1 has a different ATC code than Tylenol with codeine #3. This field can be used for either prior or concomitant medication/treatments.
fields.label: Reported Name of Drug, Med, or Therapy
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMTRT
fields.questionText: What was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] (name/term)?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMPRESP

fields.definition: An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is prespecified on a CRF.
fields.implementationNotes: For prespecified interventions, a hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM dataset creation. If a study collects both prespecified interventions as well as free-text interventions, the value of CMPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified interventions and null for interventions reported as free text.
fields.label: CM Pre-Specified
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMPRESP

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMOCCUR

fields.completionInstructions: Indicate if [specific medication/treatment] was taken by checking Yes or No.
fields.definition: An indication whether the prespecified medication/treatment/therapy (CMTRT) or the group of medications/treatments/therapies was administered when information about the occurrence of a specific intervention is solicited.
fields.implementationNotes: CMOCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a prespecific medication/treatment. CMOCCUR is not used for spontaneously free text reported concomitant medication/treatments. The site should be able to indicate that the response was not asked or answered.
fields.label: CM Occurrence
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target". If the response was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable CMSTAT with "NOT DONE".
fields.name: CMOCCUR
fields.questionText: Did the subject take [prespecified (concomitant) medication/treatment/therapy/dose]?; Has the subject taken [prespecified (concomitant) medication/treatment/therapy/dose]?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMINGRD

fields.completionInstructions: Prior to a subject's clinical visit, remind all subjects to bring all medications bottles, packs etc. they are taking with them to their clinical visit. Record all active ingredient(s) off the medication label and separate each ingredient with a comma for the name of drug medication or treatment taken. For example, the medication Dolmen, if manufactured in Spain, the active ingredients should be collected as noted below: Active Ingredient: Acetylsalicylic Acid, Ascorbic acid, codeine phosphate.
fields.definition: Medication Ingredients.
fields.implementationNotes: This may be collected in addition to the Medication/Treatment Name. Collecting this provides more detailed information when coding to a medication dictionary like WHODrug Dictionary Enhanced Format C, which now codes to the ingredient level for many trade-named medications. For example, depending on the country where it is manufactured, the active ingredients in the medication Dolmen may be different: In Spain, Acetylsalicylic Acid, Ascorbic acid, codeine phosphate; in Italy and Czech Republic, contains Tenoxicam; in Estonia and Latvia, contains Dexketoprofen trometamol.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds Active Ingredients
fields.mappingInstructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM Annotated CRF is annotated to indicate that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
fields.name: CMINGRD
fields.questionText: What were the active ingredients?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMINDC

fields.completionInstructions: Record the reason the medication was taken based on clinical investigator's evaluation. If taken to treat a condition, and a diagnosis was made, the indication should be the diagnosis. If taken to treat a condition, and no diagnosis was made, the indication should be the signs and symptoms. If taken as prophylaxis, report as "Prophylaxis for " and include a description of the condition(s).
fields.definition: The condition, disease, symptom, or disorder that the concomitant (non-study) medication/treatment/therapy was used to address or investigate (e.g., why the medication/treatment/therapy was taken or administered).
fields.implementationNotes: This is not the pharmacological/therapeutic classification of an agent (e.g., antibiotic, analgesic), but the reason for its administration to the subject. This additional information is collected on the CRF when sponsors want to capture the reason(s) why a subject took a medication/treatment. This information could be used as deemed appropriate for coding, analysis (e.g., in the classification of medications), for reconciling the medications/treatments taken by a subject with provided medical history, and/or AEs/SAEs as part of the data clean-up and monitoring process.
fields.label: CM Indication
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMINDC
fields.questionText: For what indication was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] taken?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMAENO

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier of the Adverse Event for which this (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] was taken.
fields.definition: Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this medication/treatment/therapy.
fields.implementationNotes: Intent is to establish a link between the medication/treatment and the AE that was reported. CMAENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in CM dataset and records in the AE dataset. See SDTMIG v3.2 Section 8.2 for information on RELREC.
fields.label: Related Adverse Event ID
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the Adverse Events domain.
fields.name: CMAENO
fields.questionText: What was the identifier for the adverse event(s) for which the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] was taken?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMMHNO

fields.completionInstructions: Record the identifier of the medical history event for which this (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] was taken.
fields.definition: Identifier for the medical history condition that is the indication for this medication/treatment/therapy.
fields.implementationNotes: Intent is to establish a link between the medical history condition and the medication/treatment taken for the medical history condition. CMMHNO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the CM dataset and records in the MH dataset. See SDTMIG v3.2 Section 8.2 for information on RELREC.
fields.label: Related Medical History Event ID
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the Medical History domain.
fields.name: CMMHNO
fields.questionText: What was the identifier for the medical history event(s) for which the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] was taken?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSE

fields.completionInstructions: Record the dose of (concomitant) [medication/treatment] taken per administration (e.g., 200).
fields.definition: The dose of medication/treatment (e.g., --TRT ) given at one time represented as a numeric value.
fields.implementationNotes: Used when the dose/amount taken/administered/consumed has only numeric entries. If non-numeric entries are possible, use the CDASH field CMDSTXT.
fields.label: CM Dose per Administration
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDOSE
fields.questionText: What was the individual dose (of the concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] per administration)?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDSTXT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the dose of (concomitant) [medication/treatment] taken per administration (e.g., 200).
fields.definition: The dose of medication/treatment taken per administration.
fields.implementationNotes: Defining this data collection field as a dose text field allows for flexibility in capturing dose entries as numbers, text or ranges. The data collected in this dose text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTMIG CMDOSE if numeric or CMDOSTXT if text.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds Dose Description
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to CMDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to CMDOSTXT in SDTM.
fields.name: CMDSTXT
fields.questionText: What was the individual dose of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSTOT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the total dose of (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] taken daily.
fields.definition: The total amount of CMTRT taken over a day using the units in CMDOSU.
fields.implementationNotes: For use when only total daily dose is collected in the CRF. For general medications/treatments, it is not recommended to use Total Daily Dose. Instead, this can be calculated from other fields such as Units, Dose, and Frequency.
fields.label: CM Total Daily Dose
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDOSTOT
fields.questionText: What was the total daily dose of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C71620
Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C78417

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSU

fields.completionInstructions: Record the dose unit of the dose of concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] taken (e.g., mg.).
fields.definition: The unit associated with the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy taken (e.g., mg in "2 mg 3 times per day").
fields.implementationNotes: When sponsors collect data for amount of dose taken (i.e., Dose, Total Daily Dose), Unit must be collected as well (if applicable).
fields.label: CM Dose Units
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDOSU
fields.questionText: What is the unit (for the dose of concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy])?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66726
Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C78418

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSFRM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the pharmaceutical dosage form (e.g., TABLET CAPSULE, SYRUP) of delivery for the concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] taken.
fields.definition: The pharmaceutical dosage form in which the CMTRT is physically presented.
fields.implementationNotes: Some drugs have multiple forms and this field may be needed to code the drug to an ATC level. However, in general, this level of detail should not be necessary except for medications/treatments of interest.
fields.label: CM Dose Form
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDOSFRM
fields.questionText: What was the dose form of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C71113
Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C78419

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

priorVersion.title: Concomitant Meds Dosing Frequency per Interval

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDOSFRQ

fields.completionInstructions: Record how often the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] was taken (e.g., BID, PRN).
fields.definition: The number of doses given/administered/taken during a specific interval.
fields.implementationNotes: The frequency of the concomitant medication/treatment. When collected, the recommendation is to collect dosing information in separate fields (e.g., CMDOSE, CMDOSEU, CMDOSFRQ) for specific and consistent data collection and to enable programmatically utilizing these data.
fields.label: CM Dosing Frequency per Interval
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDOSFRQ
fields.questionText: What was the frequency of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66729
Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C78420

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMROUTE

fields.completionInstructions: Provide the route of administration for the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy].
fields.definition: The route of administration of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy].
fields.implementationNotes: This additional information may be important to collect on the CRF when the sponsor would want to capture a medication's/treatment's route of administration for purposes such as coding and the medication/treatment may have more than one route. Some companies may use route in coding medications/treatments to be able to choose a precise preferred name and ATC code.
fields.label: CM Route of Administration
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMROUTE
fields.questionText: What was the route of administration of the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy]?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSTDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the concomitant [medication/treatment] was first taken using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has been taking the concomitant [medication/treatment] for a considerable amount of time prior to the start of the study, it is acceptable to have an incomplete date. Concomitant [medication/treatment] taken during the study are expected to have a complete start date. Prior concomitant [medication/treatment] that are exclusionary should have both a start and end date.
fields.definition: The start date when the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy was first taken, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.implementationNotes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have a Start Date or will indicate that the medication or therapy was started before, during or after the study period. The preferred method is to collect a complete Start Date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for medications/treatment started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds Start Date
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CMSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMSTDAT
fields.questionText: What was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy/dose] start date?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMSTTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the concomitant [medication/treatment] was started.
fields.definition: The time the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy was started, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
fields.implementationNotes: Recommend collecting the time a concomitant medication/treatment was started only when a protocol or data collection scenarios supports it. Typically, a start time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a concomitant medication/treatment administered or the subject records the start time in a diary. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and SDTMIG v3.2 Section 4.1.4.7 for more information.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds Start Time
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CMSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMSTTIM
fields.questionText: What was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy/dose] start time?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMPRIOR

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: Start Relative to Reference Time Point

fields.completionInstructions: Check if the concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] was started before the study.
fields.definition: Indication the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy was given or taken prior to [CMSTTPT] or prior to the date in DM.RFSTDTC.
fields.implementationNotes: Sponsors may collect this information rather than start dates. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and SDTMIG v3.2 Section 4.1.4.7 for more information.
fields.label: Prior Concomitant Meds
fields.mappingInstructions:
This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as CMSTRF or CMSTRTPT. When populating CMSTRF, or CMSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field CMPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When CMPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable CMSTRF should be populated. When CMPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTM variables CMSTRTPT and CMSTTPT should be used. When CMONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variables CMENRTPT and CMENTPT should be used. 
 Note: CMSTRTPT must refer to the time point anchor described in CMSTTPT.
fields.name: CMPRIOR
fields.questionText: Was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] given/taken prior to [CMSTTPT]?; Was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] given/taken prior to study start?

codelist.title: Version-agnostic anchor resource for codelist C66742

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMONGO

sdtmigDatasetMappingTargets.title: End Relative to Reference Time Point

fields.completionInstructions: Record the concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] as ongoing if the subject has not stopped taking the concomitant [medication/treatment/therapy] at [the timepoint defined by the study]. If the concomitant medication is ongoing, the end date should be left blank
fields.definition: Indication the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy is ongoing when no end date is provided.
fields.implementationNotes: This box should be checked to indicate that the concomitant medication/treatment has not stopped at the time of data collection. It is expected that every recorded medication/treatment should have either an End Date or be checked as Ongoing, but not both. However, in cases where ongoing concomitant medications/treatments are not permitted, it may not be necessary to include an Ongoing field in the CRF. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submission, for more information about collecting relative date/time; see SDTMIG v3.2 Section 4.1.4 for information about mapping relative times.
fields.label: Ongoing Concomitant Meds
fields.mappingInstructions:
This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as CMENRF or CMENRTPT. When populating CMENRF, if the value of CMONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating CMENRTPT, if the value of CMONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When CMONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable CMENRF should be populated. When CMONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variables CMENRTPT and CMENTPT should be used. 
 Note: CMENRTPT must refer to a time point anchor described in CMENTPT.
fields.name: CMONGO
fields.prompt: Ongoing (as of [the study-specific time point or period])
fields.questionText: Was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy] ongoing (as of [the study-specific time point or period])?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMENDAT

fields.completionInstructions: Record the date the concomitant [medication/treatment] was stopped using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has not stopped taking the concomitant [medication/treatment] leave this field blank.
fields.definition: The date that the subject ended/stopped taking the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
fields.implementationNotes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have an End Date or will indicate that the medication or therapy was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the End Date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an End Date in the CRF. For example, if all concomitant medications/treatments are administered only once during a trial, the End Date will be the same as the Start Date.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds End Date
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CMENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMENDAT
fields.questionText: What was the (concomitant) [medication/treatment/therapy/dose] end date?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMENTIM

fields.completionInstructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the concomitant medication/treatment was stopped.
fields.definition: The time when the subject ended/stopped taking the concomitant medication/treatment/therapy represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
fields.implementationNotes: Recommend collecting the time a concomitant medication or treatment was ended only when a protocol or data collection scenarios require it or the subject records the start time in a diary. Typically, an end time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a concomitant medication/treatment is stopped.
fields.label: Concomitant Meds End Time
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CMENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
fields.name: CMENTIM
fields.questionText: What was the [medication/treatment/therapy/dose] end time?

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

priorVersion.title: Concomitant Meds Dictionary or Standardized Term

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMDECOD

fields.definition: The dictionary- or sponsor-defined standardized text description of the topic variable, CMTRT, or the modified topic variable (CMMODIFY), if applicable.
fields.implementationNotes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. Equivalent to the generic drug name in WHODrug, or a term in SNOMED, ICD9, or other published or sponsor-defined dictionaries.
fields.label: Standardized Medication Name
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMDECOD

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMCLAS

fields.definition: The class for the intervention, often obtained from a coding dictionary.
fields.implementationNotes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This would generally be the class used for analysis.
fields.label: CM Medication Class
fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMCLAS

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

fields.mappingInstructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading "SDTMIG Target".
fields.name: CMCLASCD

parentProduct.title: Clinical Data Acquisition Standards Harmonization Implementation Guide for Human Clinical Trials Version 2.1

rootItem.title: Version-agnostic anchor element for field CM.CMATC1

fields.definition: Dictionary text description of the first level of hierarchy within the Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical Classification System. Indicates the anatomical main group.
fields.implementationNotes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. This is populated through the sponsor's coding process.
fields.label: ATC Level 1 Description
fields.mappingInstructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPCM dataset as the value of SUPPCM.QVAL where SUPPCM.QNAM="CMATC1" and SUPPCM.QLABEL="ATC Level 1 Description". Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.
fields.name: CMATC1
